description: Coaching rubric for Customer Success Managers focusing on value realization, risk management, and customer retention/expansion

dimensions.name: Value Realization Tracking
criteria: Tracks metrics showing customer ROI and value from Prefect
Identifies blockers preventing customers from realizing expected value
Probes on business outcomes and success metrics customer cares about
Documents value achieved in customer's language (time saved, cost reduced, etc.)
Creates success plans with measurable milestones and goals

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Comprehensive value tracking with specific metrics and ROI. Proactively identifies and addresses value realization blockers. Deep understanding of customer success criteria. Well-documented value achievements. Clear success plan with milestones.
scoring.70-89: Good: Tracks main value metrics, identifies some blockers. Understands key customer success outcomes. Documents value adequately. Has success plan with reasonable goals.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Limited value tracking, vague metrics. Misses some blockers to value realization. Superficial understanding of customer success needs. Minimal documentation. Weak or generic success plan.
scoring.0-49: Poor: No value tracking or ROI measurement. Doesn't identify blockers. No understanding of customer success criteria. No documentation of value. No success plan.

dimensions.name: Risk Identification
criteria: Spots early warning signs of dissatisfaction, churn risk, or disengagement
Probes on renewal likelihood, budget concerns, and competitive threats
Assesses health of stakeholder relationships and executive sponsorship
Identifies technical adoption challenges or unused features
Creates mitigation plans for identified risks

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Detects all key risk signals early. Directly addresses renewal concerns and competitive threats. Thorough assessment of relationship health and adoption. Proactive mitigation plans for all major risks.
scoring.70-89: Good: Identifies most important risks. Addresses renewal and budget concerns. Assesses key relationships. Has mitigation approach for main risks.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Misses some risk signals. Superficial discussion of renewal. Limited relationship assessment. Reactive rather than proactive on risk mitigation.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Doesn't detect or address risk signals. Avoids renewal discussions. No assessment of relationship health. No risk mitigation planning.

dimensions.name: Relationship Depth
criteria: Builds trusted advisor relationship with customer stakeholders
Demonstrates genuine partnership and investment in customer success
Expands relationships beyond initial champion to economic buyer and exec sponsor
Shows empathy and understanding of customer's business pressures
Maintains regular, proactive communication and follow-through

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Clear trusted advisor status with multiple stakeholders. Customer sees CSM as partner, not vendor. Strong relationships at multiple levels including exec sponsor. Deep empathy for customer challenges. Consistent, proactive engagement.
scoring.70-89: Good: Strong relationship with main stakeholders. Customer trusts CSM's guidance. Some executive relationships. Shows empathy. Regular communication with good follow-through.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Transactional relationship, limited trust. Narrow stakeholder coverage. Weak or no executive relationships. Limited empathy. Inconsistent communication or follow-through.
scoring.0-49: Poor: No meaningful relationship, purely reactive. Customer doesn't trust CSM. Single point of contact only. No empathy. Poor communication and follow-through.

dimensions.name: Expansion Opportunity Spotting
criteria: Identifies use cases for additional seats, features, or products
Asks about adjacent teams or departments that could benefit from Prefect
Uncovers budget and timing for expansion opportunities
Positions expansion as path to greater value realization, not just upsell
Coordinates with AE on commercial expansion discussions

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Identifies multiple concrete expansion opportunities with clear business case. Understands budget and timing. Frames expansion as value driver, not just revenue. Seamless coordination with AE on commercial aspects.
scoring.70-89: Good: Spots main expansion opportunities. Has some understanding of budget/timing. Decent value framing. Coordinates with AE on expansion discussions.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Misses obvious expansion opportunities. Vague on budget/timing. Expansion feels like pushy upselling. Limited coordination with AE.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Doesn't identify any expansion opportunities. No discussion of additional use cases or teams. No budget/timing awareness. No AE coordination.

dimensions.name: Product Adoption Coaching
criteria: Identifies underutilized features that could drive more value
Provides practical guidance on best practices and implementation patterns
Shares relevant resources, documentation, or training materials
Removes technical blockers or escalates to appropriate team
Celebrates customer wins and progress milestones

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Proactively identifies adoption opportunities for underused features. Provides actionable guidance and resources. Efficiently removes blockers. Celebrates customer progress and wins. Drives increasing product usage.
scoring.70-89: Good: Spots some adoption opportunities. Provides helpful guidance. Shares relevant resources. Resolves some blockers. Acknowledges customer progress.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Misses adoption opportunities. Generic guidance. Limited resources shared. Slow on resolving blockers. Minimal celebration of wins.
scoring.0-49: Poor: No adoption coaching. No guidance or resources provided. Blockers go unaddressed. Doesn't celebrate customer progress.
